(4/4) About 70% of the black carbon in the Arctic currently comes from fossil fuel burning in Northern countries while the remainder is largely from wildfires and agricultural burning.

#climatechange @ScienceAdvances https://t.co/1CAzJ91CW3 @insideclimate https://t.co/TBftQAkI9p

(3/4) Once it falls, black carbon darkens the surface of ice and snow, where it absorbs energy from sunlight. That causes melting on the surface while also reducing how well ice reflects solar radiation back into space.

#climatechange #blackcarbon #arctic #icemelt #science

(2/4) Black carbon stays aloft for only a few days to weeks before falling. While airborne, it is a short-lived climate pollutant that is many times more potent than carbon dioxide at warming the atmosphere, though it has a far shorter lifespan. 

#climatechange #blackcarbon

(1/4) A new study finds the burning of fossil fuels (not wildfires) are the biggest source of the key Arctic climate pollutant, black carbon. Black carbon contributes to global warming & ice melt.

#climatechange #blackcarbon #icemelt @ScienceAdvances https://t.co/1CAzJ91CW3 https://t.co/gb1JDgM2cO
